title: Train pain could be eased as revolutionary British software helps commuters find space on packed carriages
text:
The pain of thousands of commuters could be eased thanks to new technology telling you where to stand on the platform for the least-crowded carriage.
Currently being developed by a British software startup, Open Capacity is a project aiming to make that dream a reality.
It works by analysing information from weight sensors on board each carriage that show how many people are currently riding it. These weight sensors are used by drivers to help the train take corners properly.
Crowded platform at London Bridge train station, London, England, UK
When the weight of the carriage is matched to historical data that includes CCTV footage and ticket barriers at different stations, it's possible to discern how the people are spaced. And to predict future behaviour.
Once completed, Open Capacity could be used to display information on station platforms around the country advising people on the best place to stand.
It could also be used as an app on a smartphone to let people make their commute more efficient.
The Open Capacity software could revolutionise crowded British commutes
"By distributing people along the platform it can reduce boarding and alighting time, to make the trains more punctual," Gerrit Boehm, a PhD graduate from University College London who came up with the idea, told the Times.
Open Capacity is currently working with train operators and hopes to have a working version of the software to demo by the end of the month.
